conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D, and the task is to predict whether it flows into container E or F after passing through baffles.
Each coloured outlet at the top (A, B, C, D) releases a vertical stream of liquid.
On its way down, the liquid strikes the sloping baffles.
A stream that lands on the upper surface of a baffle runs to the baffle’s lower end due to gravity and then falls straight down from that point.
A stream that misses a baffle simply continues straight down.
The long yellow baffle’s lower end is on the left side of the box.
Any stream that lands on the yellow baffle will finally drop from the left half of the box.
The grey baffle on the right has its lower end on the right side of the box.
Liquid landing on the grey baffle drops from the right half of the box.
The short white and brown baffles lie lower in the box.
The short white and brown baffles only reinforce the left-versus-right division and do not cross the central dividing line between the two collecting regions.
The vertical division between the two groups of bottom U-shaped troughs (E on the left, F on the right) sits approximately under the middle of the box.
A and B are released far enough left that they fall on the yellow baffle and are carried to the left half, leading to container group E.
C starts near the middle but still lands on the upper part of the yellow baffle, so it ends up in container group E.
D is released far right, misses the yellow baffle, lands on (or to the right of) the grey baffle, and is directed to the right half, leading to container group F.
Final prediction: A → E, B → E, C → E, D → F.
